data.title: Fixed a bug in the ContentWriter.cs where when processing List<T> types
data.body:
When processing the List<Rectangle> in a sprite font we get an error about the typewriter not existing. 
Changing this index lookup to be based on Type rather than instance fixes the issue

data.title: Blurry or buggy sprite font on windows 8
data.body:
There is a problem with displaying spritefonts under windows 8 (it seems), the original question can be seen here

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18503410/blurry-spritefont-on-monogame-win8

This is totally functional under windows 8 XNA 4.0

data.title: Improving BlendState/RasterizerState/DepthStencilState.ToString()
data.body:
Fix: BlendState.ToString() to not display "Opaque" for all custom states.
Improvement: BlendState.ToString() now displays the short type name instead of the namespace-qualified type name.
Improvement: Added ToString() to DepthStencilState and RasterizerState, mirroring the implementation of BlendState.ToString().

Note that these methods are primarily for improving workflow while debugging, since these objects are displayed in the watch window by the evaluation of their ToString() method.

data.title: Fixes Texture2D.GetData to consider row pitch on DirectX versions.
data.body:
Fixes Texture2D.GetData to consider row pitch on DirectX versions.

I've made a lot of test cases and tested them on Microsoft XNA and with Windows8 version of MonoGame. They all worked exactly the same.

data.title: Is there any benefit to having ARM / x86 / x64 specific builds for Windows 8?
data.body:
While doing the NuGet packages I noticed that the Windows 8 build is built against AnyCPU

Was there any specific reason for this or should there be build specific targets and is there any good reason to do so?

data.title: Game now correctly disposed on exit of the activity
data.body: Game can now be exited and re-launched on Android multiple times without errors.

data.title: Kill Process On Exit
data.body: Kill process on exit for consistency with other platforms (killing process clears its memory, preventing static data persisting between runs - potentially dangerous with complex games)

data.title: Update to project templates to use .Targets files instead of individual references
data.body:
While creating New samples and the NuGet installer thee was an increasing need to simplify how to reference MonoGame libs and dependant references.

SO I've crafted .Targets files for each supported platform. updated the project templates to use them and the build installer to copy the .targets files

Updated:
- All project templates except iOS / MacOS
- Build installer to copy new .target files
  Added:
- .Target files to Project templates folder

data.title: Update to project templates to use .Targets files instead of individual references
data.body:
While creating New samples and the NuGet installer thee was an increasing need to simplify how to reference MonoGame libs and dependant references.

SO I've crafted .Targets files for each supported platform. updated the project templates to use them and the build installer to copy the .targets files

data.title: Monogame App Doesn't Run in Linux
data.body:
Relevant code: 

``` C#
     private void RenderVertices(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice GraphicsDevice,Texture2D texture2D,VertexPositionNormalTexture[] vertices)
            {
                Effect.Texture = null;
                Effect.Texture = texture2D;
                foreach (EffectPass pass in Effect.CurrentTechnique.Passes)
                {
                    pass.Apply();
                    GraphicsDevice.DrawUserPrimitives<VertexPositionNormalTexture>(
                        PrimitiveType.TriangleList, 
                        vertices, 0, 2);

                }
            } 
```

App compiled and ran successfully on a Windows machine. On Linux (debian-base), running the app causes the following: 

```
Unhandled Exception: System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object
  at OpenTK.Graphics.ES11.GL.EnableClientState (All array) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0
```

data.title: Fix RenderTarget creation if called from non UI thread
data.body: Reloading resources after resume on Android (and probably other GL platforms with device reset on resume) could cause rendertargets to turn black (invalid). This simple change should fix that.

data.title: Fix for game init when running under unit test runner
data.body:
I was trying to run some tests on a class inheriting Game and was encountering NullReferenceExceptions. The class worked fine when being run directly. After some debugging I found this use of Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly() and added a null check.

It turns out this was already fixed in a few other files in:
Unit Test Fixes by tomspilman · Pull Request #1530 · mono/MonoGame

Then I found some topic like this in PSM DevPortal

http://community.eu.playstation.com/t5/General/Write-text-file/td-p/15887357

i try to use "/Documents" as StorageRoot, it works

sorry for my english

data.title: ReflectiveReader property/field order
data.body:
ReflectiveReader depends on order of properties and fields returned by GetProperties reflection method. According to MSDN (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/kyaxdd3x.aspx) this order may vary.

> “The GetProperties method does not return properties in a particular order, such as alphabetical or declaration order. Your code must not depend on the order in which properties are returned, because that order varies.“

Therefore the deserialization may fail in some (random?) circumstances. 
Possible hot-fix is to sort properties/fields by their MetadataToken (http://hoonzis.blogspot.sk/2012/09/reflection-order-of-discovered.html ), but this order is also not guaranteed.
I think that the best way to solve this problem is to use order defined in attribute or to sort properties/fields in alphabetical order. But this is probably going to break compatibility with XNA (which has the same bug).

data.title: Fixed crash when the output directory does not exist for SongProcessor
data.body:
Ensure the output directory exists for WMA files otherwise we crash.
We ensure the output directory exists in PipelineBuildEvent.Save but WMA files are saved early

data.title: Song issue seems to persist on WinDX.
data.body:
I saw pull #1874 had apparently fixed this on the WinDX project.  However I'm still getting the exact same error occurring on the catch call.  Same exact issue.  It'll play occasionally, but usually just throws the exception referenced in #1874.

Brought it up here.  https://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/453847

Could someone confirm this this should be fixed, and if so, what would cause it to still occur for me?  I even went as far as to delete and re-download the whole repo just to make sure I was all up to date.  I'm hoping to release a windows title in a few weeks so I really appreciate any input on this.

data.title: Fix Texture2D PVRTC size computation
data.body:
PVRTC imagesize computation was inverted between PVRTC 2bpp and PVRTC 4bpp (see Issue 6 in http://www.khronos.org/registry/gles/extensions/IMG/IMG_texture_compression_pvrtc.txt for source)

Also added missing support to initialize a Texture2D with ETC1 surfaceformat

data.title: Add support for border color clamp texture addressing
data.body: As mentioned here (https://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/454253), it would be nice to have a border color clamp texture address mode.  XNA 3.0 had it, but XNA 4.0 got rid of it.  From the reading I did, it seemed they ditched it because the Windows Mobile platform didn't support it.  It would certainly be nice to have it back.

data.title: Mouse.cs GetState crashes in PSM
data.body: With the current repository and executing the examples from https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples  , GetState() crashes because PrimaryWindow is null

data.title: Disabled Windows Touch Helpers
data.body: This disables the various touch helpers in GameWindow when running on the Windows 7/8 desktop (like the press & hold context box).  These popup  during gameplay unless explicitly disabled when the WM_TABLET_QUERYSYSTEMGESTURESTA is sent.

data.title: TouchPanel.EnableMouseTouchPoint not working on MacOS
data.body:
Setting TouchPanel.EnableMouseTouchPoint = true does not register mouse events on MacOS.

The same code works on WinDX.

data.body: Make Texture2D.FromStream() available for Windows Phone 8

data.body: Merge Overdo

data.title: Loading a PNG with alpha and rendering not working correctly on Windows GL
data.body:
This issue affect MonoGame on Windows GL but may affect other platforms too. It affects MonoGame 3.0, and also 3.2.

Basically loading a texture with this code (F#):

```
use file = System.IO.File.OpenRead("testTexture.png")
this.texture <- Texture2D.FromStream(this.GraphicsDevice, file)
```

and rendering with this code:

```
this.spriteBatch.Begin(SpriteSortMode.Immediate, BlendState.NonPremultiplied);
this.spriteBatch.Draw(this.texture, Vector2.Zero, Color.White)
this.spriteBatch.End()
```

will reproduce the error. This code works fine and renders fine when using the XNA4 libraries, but has weird alpha blending artefacts when using MonoGame.

Here's some renderings to illustrate the issue. First the correct renderings using the XNA libraries
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/2Rtqhuk.png)

Now the bad renderings using MonoGame:

![Image](http://i.imgur.com/Dny26gI.png)

I've tried to figure out the nature of the issue, but havne;t gotten very far besides realising that it's not a simple case of `BlendState.NonPremultiplied` being ignored or something similar. For examples, on analysis I've noticed the green colour channel blends differently than the red and blue colour channels among other odd things. I've creates a large image that illustrates the issue I've noticed in what is hopefully a useful way:

http://i.imgur.com/CEUQqm0.png

Here's the project files for reproducing the bad rendering (F# project):
http://www.qfpost.com/file/d?g=EhZh52Zjc

I also made a post about this issue on stack overflow which may be worth monitoring:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18320633/loading-texture-form-png-in-monogame-transaprency-issue

data.title: Migration of MonoGame to Protobuild
data.body: Protobuild is a cross-platform project generation system, addressing https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1722.

data.title: Added support for EXT versions of OpenGL framebuffer object (FBO) method...
data.body:
This patch adds support for the EXT versions of the OpenGL framebuffer object (FBO) methods. The EXT versions will only be used if the ARB versions are not supported. It will also check for FBO support and throw an exception if it's not supported.

This should address issues reported in issue #998 and also issue #811.

I tested this under Windows 7 on my laptop (which only has the EXT FBO methods) and also my desktop (which supports the ARB versions). This should also work under Linux and MacOS, but I was unable to test this. I also had to make changes to all other projects using OpenGL to support this patch, but I was also unable to test this. Hopefully I haven't missed anything and everything is still working as expected.

PS. This is my first every pull request, so please be gentle :)

data.body: Removing [Flags] From the Keys.cs enum as discussed in #1942

``` C#
                case 0x2a: // LShift

```

For some reason I can't understand, after that line is executed, it tells me the Key is Space | F17 ?  If i take the annotation off it works, but I don't see why we should have to do that...


Any thoughts? I know it was working as of a couple weeks ago.

data.title: Expand GraphicsProfile Beyond Reach/HiDef
data.body:
We need to decide how to expand the existing `GraphicsProfile` system beyond the old Reach/HiDef options from XNA 4.

We have a few options:
- Go back to cap bits.
- Expand `GraphicsProfile` with more profiles.
- Add a new `FeatureLevel` enum similar to DirectX feature levels.

Cap bits enable "full flexibility" but it puts the burden all on the end user to figure out what combinations of bits are common.  I don't think anyone wants to go to cap bits... even if they say they do.  This is what sucked about DX9 and what IMO still sucks about OpenGL.

I could see expanding the existing `GraphicsProfile` to support more profiles:

```
public enum GraphicsProfile
{
    XboxOne,
    PlayStation4,                    
    HiDef,
    MidDef,
    LowDef,
    Reach,
    Limited
}
```

Some special platform specific profiles could be nice, but maybe sticking to more generic profiles is better?

The final option here is just mimicking the feature level concept from DirectX.  This is sort of what `GraphicsProfile` does albeit with only two levels.  Having it as a new separate enum just gives us some flexibility to break with the old system.

With either feature levels or profiles we will still need to look at all the different platforms MonoGame targets and all the hardware variations and make some calls as to how to decide how to categorize any particular hardware device.  We then need to clearly document these rules for developers.

data.title: Fixed strange sound loading issue on MacOS
data.body:
Sometimes (Not sure why!) SoundEffect buffer reports -1 ChannelsPerFrame, and treats it as stereo even being a mono sound. This results in a sound played at twice the speed, very high pitched.

It can happen to different sounds on two consecutive runs of the game, so it's pretty random right now.

Since on XNA all sounds had to be Mono (Or so I think), treating this case as Mono "fixes" the issue.
